column1: The 2010–2012 Algerian protests were a series of protests taking place throughout Algeria
column2: lasting from 28 December 2010 to early 2012. The protests had been inspired by similar protests across the Middle East and North Africa. Causes cited by the protesters included unemployment
column3: the lack of housing
column4: food-price inflation
column5: corruption
column6: restrictions on freedom of speech and poor living conditions. While localized protests were already commonplace over previous years
column8: an unprecedented wave of simultaneous protests and riots
column9: sparked by sudden rises in staple food prices
column10: erupted all over the country starting in January 2011.  These were quelled by government measures to lower food prices
column11: but were followed by a wave of self-immolations
column12: most of them in front of government buildings.  Opposition parties
column14: and human rights organisations then began to hold weekly demonstrations
column15: despite these being illegal without government permission under the ongoing state of emergency; the government suppressed these demonstrations as far as possible
column16: but in late February yielded to pressure and lifted the state of emergency.  Meanwhile
column22: occurring almost daily in towns scattered all over the country.

column2: the Algerian government had moved towards democracy
column3: holding free elections.  However
column4: when the Islamic Salvation Front (FIS) won the

column2: the military staged a coup d'état
column3: voided the election results
column4: declared a state of emergency which remained in force until 2011
column5: and arrested the FIS leadership.  This led to the founding of the Armed Islamic Groups (GIA) and the ten-year Algerian Civil War

column1: With the unchallenged election of Abdelaziz Bouteflika as president in 1999
column2: civilian government was nominally restored.  Violence died down as both guerrillas and soldiers were given immunity for their previous acts under the controversial Charter for Peace and National Reconciliation.  Towards the end of his second term
column3: Bouteflika amended the constitution to allow himself to run for a third term in 2009; to no one's surprise
column4: he won the ensuing election

column1: Seventy percent of Algeria's population is less than 30 years old. Consequent high levels of youth unemployment
column2: coupled with corruption and widespread poverty
column3: are seen as reasons for dissatisfaction.The leader of the Rally for Culture and Democracy
column4: Saïd Sadi

column7: 700 riots and unrests" in Algeria. Some protests were about issues such as education and health care
column8: as well as rampant corruption.Prior to the outbreak of protests
column10: United States Ambassador Robert Ford in leaked diplomatic cables called Algeria  "an unhappy country"
column11: stating "There is much discussion among political circles about the constitution
column12: the third term and the succession issue
column13: but precious little discussion about how to address long-standing political alienation and social discontent throughout the country." He claimed there were strikes over food "by different labor groups almost weekly" and that "almost daily there are isolated demonstrations with the occasional government office in some distant town attacked." Ford stated that "voter turnout for the 2007 legislative and local elections was lower than ever before because Algeria's young people do not see the political system as having any relevance to addressing their problem." United States diplomats also claimed that the Algerian regime is more corrupt than the international community realises and is also more fragile. The diplomatic cable also said that Bouteflika may have cancer.

column2: clashes with police were reported in Algiers during protests about the lack of housing. At least 53 people were reported to have been injured and another 29 were arrested.
3–10 January 2011 ==
prices of basic foodstuffs rose significantly in Algeria
column3: in line with global trends but also reflecting newly imposed regulations. Unprecedented protests in neighbouring Tunisia over unemployment were already being reported
column4: contributing to the mood.

column2: riots and protests broke out across most Algerian towns
column3: triggered by large increases in the prices of basic foods including oil
column4: sugar
column5: and flour. While localised riots have been a frequent occurrence in Algeria since 2005
column6: this set of riots was the first to spread across most regions of the country simultaneously rather than being confined to a particular area. By 10 January they were limited to a few towns
column7: but continued in those towns. More organised efforts to demonstrate on 11 January in Algiers were suppressed vigorously by the police.Protests against the price increases started on 3 January
column8: with protest in the Ras El Ain quarter of Oran
column9: and in Fouka and Staoueli near Algiers. On 4 January they were repeated in Staoueli and spread to other areas near the capital
column10: with impromptu roadblocks at Douaouda in Tipasa. and KoleaOn 5 January
column11: major riots broke out in several areas at once: in the Bab El Oued neighbourhood of the capital
column14: as well as Algeria's second city
column19: and Tipaza. The young men rioting blocked roads
column22: protesting the sudden increase in the cost of living
column24: and broader issues such as unemployment. They were met by anti-riot forces
column25: who attempted to disperse the crowds. In Bab El Oued
column26: shops and car showrooms were also targeted. Former Islamic Salvation Front number two Ali Belhadj went to Bab El Oued to see the events and encourage the youths; he was arrested later that day
column27: as were many other protesters and rioters.Within days the riots spread to twenty-odd wilayahs
column28: covering almost the whole of the north including the Kabylie region
column29: as well as some towns in the Sahara
column30: such as Ouargla and Bechar. Government buildings
column33: and shops in some areas were looted or burned; some of the looters carried swords. Football matches scheduled for 7 and 8 January were cancelled.On 8 January
column34: the government agreed to a temporary cut in taxes and duties on sugar and cooking oil. Facebook and Twitter access were also restricted in some areas. The rioting continued
column35: at least up to 10 January in some places
column36: such as the Bachdjarrah neighbourood in Algiers. By 11 January
column37: the situation had calmed. An attempt to demonstrate on 11 January in Algiers
column38: organised in advance by the intercommunal committee of Ain Benian and Staoueli
column39: was repressed vigorously by the police. In total
column41: more than 800 people had been wounded

column1: While riots on this scale are unprecedented since the 1991 election
column2: their wider political implications are not yet clear.  The rioters had no collective ties to any Algerian political party
column3: organisation
column4: or trade union
column5: and some sources commented that they seemed to have no political slogans. Some opposition groups emphasised the riots' political dimension; ex-diplomat and opposition spokesperson Mohamed Larbi Zitout described them as "a revolt
column8: while the Socialist Forces Front responded to the government's lowering of food prices on 8 January with the slogan "The government cannot buy Algerians' silence". Agence France-Presse (AFP) has linked the January protests with events in Tunisia
column11: similar unrest sparked the overthrow of the government of Zine Al Abidine Ben Ali
column12: whose 23 years in power ended with his flight to Saudi Arabia last Friday. Algerian commentators have said that more Tunisia-style protests could break out in Algeria." Despite their scale
column13: the riots were dealt with by the government in much the same way as the localised riots that had already become a routine way of communicating grievances: it sought to avoid creating martyrs and made a specific concession (in this case
column14: a return to the status quo ante of allowing un-declared food sales by Cevital) not seen as threatening the overall system.

column1: As the widely reported protests sparked off by Mohamed Bouazizi's self-immolation in Tunisia began to have a clear impact on the Tunisian government
column2: a wave of self-immolations swept Algeria.  These individual acts of protest mostly took place in front of a government building following an unsuccessful approach to the authorities.  Four self-immolators have died of their burns so far.It began on 12 January
column3: when 26-year-old Mohamed Aouichia set himself on fire in Bordj Menaiel in the compound of the daira building. He had been sharing a room of 30 square metres with seven other people
column4: including his sister
column5: since 2003; he had repeatedly approached local authorities to get on the social housing list and been rebuffed. He has so far survived.

column2: Mohsen Bouterfif
column3: a 37-year-old father of two
column4: set himself on fire.  He had gone with about twenty other youths to protest in front of the town hall of Boukhadra in Tebessa demanding jobs and houses
column5: after the mayor refused to receive them.  According to one testimony
column6: the mayor shouted to them: "If you have courage
column8: set yourself on fire!" His death was reported on 16 January
column9: and about 100 youths protested his death causing the provincial governor to sack the mayor. However
column10: hospital staff the following day claimed he was still alive
column11: though in critical condition. Al Jazeera described the suicide as "echoing the self-immolation that triggered the protests that toppled the leader of neighbouring Tunisia." He finally died on 24 January at a hospital in Annaba.These suicides were followed by dozens more attempted or successful self-immolations across the country
column12: so far without triggering nationwide demonstrations
column13: most of them after the Tunisian dictator Zine El Abidine Ben Ali fled his country on 14 January.

column1: Protests continued on 3 February. On the same day President Abdelaziz Bouteflika signaled at a meeting with government ministers his intention to lift the 19-year-old state of emergency in the "very near future"
column2: in what was seen as an attempt to quell opposition demands. Reportedly
column3: he also urged the cabinet to adopt measures to promote job creation and said Algeria's TV and radio should give airtime to all political parties. On 4 February
column4: Al Jazeera reported that demonstrations were planned for 12 February.While Bouteflika was said to be working to counter the planned demonstration
column5: on 8 February university students commenced an "indefinite strike" in protest against the "poor quality of teaching." On the same day
column6: an indefinite strike was also launched by professional paramedics after a call by the trade union SAP. However
column7: it was reported to have been observed in only 22 of the country's 48 provinces.

column1: The day after Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak resigned
column2: the protest gained new currency. The protests were organised by the nascent National Co-ordination for Change and Democracy
column3: an umbrella group of opposition parties
column4: civil society groups and unofficial unions. The police blocked all entry points into Algiers and put in a security cordon around May First Square in central Algiers. All opposition rallies were banned by the government
column5: though at least 2
column6: 000 protesters forced their way through the security cordon around the Square to join other demonstrators. Though minor protests occurred earlier in the day
column7: most protesters came out after noon; several thousand protestors clashed with about 30
column8: 000 police at May First Square in central Algiers. Protesters chanted "Djazair Horra Dimocratia
column9: (A free and democratic Algeria") "système dégage" ("government out") and "Yesterday Egypt
column10: today Algeria."Police fired tear gas on the protesters and arrested hundreds to possibly more than a 10
column12: including human rights activists and trade union members. The Algerian League for the Defense of Human Rights said that up to 28
column13: 000 police officers were deployed in Algiers. Many people
column14: including a member of the People's National Assembly
column16: were injured.Protesters had hoped to stay the night at the main square. At almost 19:30
column17: Thomson Reuters reported hundreds of people were leaving the demonstrations after about three hours and that the police opened their cordon to let them pass. It also said that about 200 young men from a poor neighbourhood stayed on and that some of them threw objects at the police.Protests were also reported in Constantine
column19: and Oran. There were reports of internet services like Twitter
column20: Facebook and the wider internet to have been disrupted or shut down
column22: Renesys denied this had taken place.Saïd Sadi of the RCD interpreted the large number of police as government weakness
column27: not strength." He also said that police charged at protesters and arrested 10 people outside the party offices as they celebrated Mubarak's resignation. He added that 90-year-old human rights activist Ali Yahia Abdelnour was "manhandled by the police" and that the protesters were not "an organised demonstration. It was spontaneous. It was an explosion of joy."

column1: Thousands turned out in Algiers for protests but were unable to take control of the main square.The government officially announces the end of the emergency rule. The country's council of ministers adopted a law revoking the 1993 decree that prolonged a state of emergency originally instituted the previous year
column2: stating that the "law will come into effect as soon as its imminent publication in the official journal".The state of emergency in the country was officially lifted after being published in the country's official journal
column3: responding to one of the main demands of the protesters. The move legalizes protests outside the capital of Algiers
column4: as long as the government is notified of planned demonstrations at least three days in advance. According to the country's interior minister
column5: Dahou Ould Kabila
column6: protests are still banned within Algiers because of security concerns; he said that "Algiers is targeted by leaders of terrorist groups [because] it gives them media impact.

column2: Algeria's major Islamist parties announced a coalition ahead of parliamentary elections. A leader of the Movement of Society for Peace called for more opposition parties to join the alliance "to give the best possible chance for the Arab Spring to happen in Algeria as well".

column1: == Local protests over jobs and infrastructure ==
The opposition group Rachad uploaded film of a non-violent demonstration of "more than 1000 people" demanding housing in the Said Hamdine neighbourhood of Algiers on 20 January
column2: not widely reported.On 24 January

column1: After security forces question three youths who were eating lunch in the Kabylie region during Ramadan
column2: about 300 others joined a protest lunch against the mandatory nature of fasting during the month. The head of the Kabylie Autonomy Movement Bouaziz Ait Chebib said: "We called this gathering to denounce the inquisition and persecution of citizens who

column1: DomesticIn reaction to the protests of early January
column2: starting 8 January the government decreased the prices of essential foods. Over following weeks it increased wheat supplies.On 3 February Bouteflika announced plans to lift the emergency law
column3: which prohibits protests without a permit
column4: and substitute for it new anti-terrorism laws
column5: but said that protests would remain illegal in Algiers in any case "for well-known reasons of public order". He also announced new measures to create jobs and that state-run television and radio should be open to all political parties. On 14 February
column6: his foreign minister Mourad Medelci repeated the promise to end the state of emergency law
column7: saying it would happen by the end of the month. on 22 February the cabinet voted to lift the emergency law. It also voted on a measure to alleviate unemployment.In efforts to discourage the protests organised by the CNCD
column8: the authorities played up the role of the RCD
column9: a mainly Kabyle party unpopular elsewhere in the country
column10: within them; while this tactic had some success
column11: it did not stop demonstrators from turning out in some non-Kabyle cities.

column1: International European Union – President of the European Parliament Jerzy Buzek said that he "call[ed] upon the Algerian authorities to refrain from violence and respect their citizens' right to peaceful demonstration. Any and all demonstrators arrested should be released immediately. The continuing state of emergency is unjustifiable and clearly hampers Algeria's prospects for the fair
column2: peaceful and sustainable development of the country. It is but a first step in responding to the legitimate democratic aspirations of the Algerian people
column3: but even this step has yet to materialise. Opposition groups
column4: civil society
column5: and especially young people should have the right to freely express their criticism of the government. No government can ignore the call of its people."

column1: France – Foreign Ministry spokesman Bernard Valero said regarding the demonstrations that "What is important in our eyes us is that freedom of expression is respected and that the demonstrations are able to take place freely and without violence"
column2: and welcomed the planned end to the State of Emergency.

column1: Germany – Foreign Minister Guido Westerwelle said Germany was "on the side of democrats. The German government calls on the Algerian government to renounce all recourse to violence. These are demonstrators who want freedom
column2: who are doing nothing more than exercising a human right
column3: to know the right to defend with dignity their point of view. As democrats we are on the side of democrats. I have already said that about Tunisia and Egypt. I say it again now in allusion to other countries."

column1: United States – Department of State spokesman PJ Crowley said that "We note the ongoing protests in Algeria
column2: and call for restraint on the part of the security services. In addition
column3: we reaffirm our support for the universal rights of the Algerian people
column4: including assembly and expression. These rights apply on the internet. Moreover
column5: these rights must be respected. We will continue to follow the situation closely in the days ahead."OtherRegional financial stock market indices fell on 20 February on concern of spreading instability.

column1: NGOsal-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb voiced support for the demonstrators against both the Tunisian and Algerian governments in a video released on 13 January 2011. AQIM leader Abu Musab Abdul Wadud offered military aid and training to the demonstrators.

Amnesty International issued a statement that read: "Algerians must be allowed to express themselves freely and hold peaceful protests in Algiers and elsewhere. We urge the Algerian authorities not to respond to these demands by using excessive force."

column2: the international group Anonymous declared a cyber-war on the Algerian state on the grounds of censorship
column3: following previous efforts in Tunisia. The next day they brought down the pro-government RND party website
column4: having previously brought down the sites of the Ministry of the Interior and the national TV station.
